item.title: Mead Batch #1: Of the bees and the beers
item.description: Honey Mead: Bees and Beers Ingredients We’re aiming for a first, simple batch of 5 litres, using local bee honey. 5L of Brewing water: the water from the faucet is quite hard, therefore the ion contents are dilluted by mixing it with distilled water in a 2/1 ratio. around 1 kg of local honey Applejack’s Mead Yeast Juice from a lemon Half a cup of strong tea (Earl Grey) Brewing Mix honey and water and bring to a boil.

item.title: Beer Batch #3: Czech is back
item.description: Return of the Czech The previous recipe was followed for a batch of 10L, but the hopping schedule was adapted. ) New Hopping schedule The following hopping schedule is used: The water was brought to a boil before hopping. 17g of hop was added at the start 7 g of hop was added after 30 min another 7 g was added after 45 min with a total cooking time of an hour.

item.title: Beer Batch #2: Czech Pilsner: Decoctions
item.description: Czech Pilsner: Concoctions Ingredients Brewing water: the water from the faucet is too hard for this type of beer. Therefore the ion contents are dilluted by mixing it with distilled water in a 1/1 ratio. 2 kg’s of Bohemian pilsner malt Saaz Hop pellets. Brewing Decoction Decoction is a process where part of the mash is separated from the larger part and boiled. This process was traditionally repeated 3-4 or more times and helped to get the most out of the malt.

item.title: Cider Batch #1: Backyard Apples & Hop Bells
item.description: Backyard Apples & Hop Bells Cider Ingredients Backyard picked hop from a friend, dried and stored before use. 2,5 baskets of apples from our yard, stored in the fridge. Pressing Total of 5L pressed Specific gravity: 1.050 -> estimated 6.5% EtOH after fermentation 500 mg Campden added for 24h in cooking pot with rag to allow evaporation Primary Fermentation Originally the plan was to do primary fermentation in a fermenting bucket and have a second fermentation in a Damme-Jeane.
